Now that you know me better...
How about getting up close and personal?

I'm going to show you how to build your own

Here's what you'll need.

  • Large glass jar with lid
  • A smaller jar (with cover)

that fits comfortably
inside center of larger jar

  • Nylon knee high stockings
  • Dark construction paper

or newspaper

  • Rubber band
  • Sand
  • Small pebbles
  • Spray bottle with water
  • Uncooked oatmeal
  • Used coffee grounds

Put the pebbles in the bottom of
the larger mixed with some sand.
Place the smaller jar inside the larger jar.
The mixture will help keep their jar centered.

Add soil to the larger jar, approximately
1/4 of the way up the jar.

Add about a half an inch of sand.
Alternate soil and sand until the jar is full.
Spray the soil and sand with water between
each layer making it moist but not too wet.
Leave about an inch of space at the top.

Drop some dry oatmeal and coffee grounds
into the top of your jar so
the worms have something to eat.
You can also add a few dried leaves or grass clippings.

Place about 5 worms in a jar.
You can buy them from a bait shop or
- for even more fun -
hunt them outside at dusk after a rain storm.

Cover the top of the jar with the nylon knee high
and use the rubber band to secure it.

This way the air circulates for the worms to breathe
but they can't get out.

Worms are more active in the dark
so put the jar in a paper bag or wrap it in a dark paper.
Place in a cool dark place, like a closet,
and leave it alone for two days
before you begin your observations.

Be sure to add more food and water as needed.
Use the spray bottle to keep it moist.
Don't pour water in the jar
because your worms could drown!

You wormed your way to a brand new
